messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

Objective: Execute sub task step: Step 6: Implement the group chat functionality. This includes adding methods to the User class for creating a group chat, adding or removing participants, and setting admin roles and permissions. The Group Chat can be represented as a subclass of the Contact class, with additional attributes for the name, picture, participants, and admin roles. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that group chats can be created, participants can be added or removed, and admin roles and permissions can be set correctly. 

 Note: Condition any new code files on the existing code files: ['app.py', 'requirements.txt', 'test_app.py', 'user.py', 'test_user.py', 'contact.py', 'message.py', 'test_message.py', 'group_chat.py', 'test_group_chat.py'] Fully implement these features in the code, no placeholders. You can now optionally view the existing files if you need to view them to complete the current task step. You have a limited context window so be selective about which files you view, only view the files you think you might need to view. 

 The group chat functionality has been implemented and the code has been updated, but the tests are still failing. The tests need to be updated to reflect the changes in the code.

Respond now only with a function call of one of the following functions provided: `sub_task_step_complete`, `view_files`, `run_python_file`, `pytest_files`, `write_files`, `delete_files`, and if you want to output code only use the `write_files` function to output code.

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up the Flask framework. The app.py file will serve as the entry point for the application. It will import and use the Flask framework to set up the application and define the routes for the different functionalities. Also, create a requirements.txt file to list all the necessary dependencies for the project. After setting up the basic structure, write tests to ensure that the application is set up correctly and can run without errors.

Step 2: Implement the user registration and authentication system. This includes creating the User class with attributes such as email and password, and methods for signing up and password recovery. The sign-up method should take an email and password, create a new User instance, and store it in a mock database. The password recovery method should take an email, check if a User with that email exists, and if so, return a password recovery link. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that the sign-up and password recovery methods work as expected.

Step 3: Implement the user profile functionality. This includes adding attributes to the User class for the profile picture and status message, and methods for setting these attributes. The privacy settings can be implemented as a dictionary attribute, with keys for different settings (e.g., 'last seen', 'profile picture') and values indicating who can see them (e.g., 'everyone', 'contacts only', 'no one'). After implementing this, write tests to ensure that the profile picture, status message, and privacy settings can be set and retrieved correctly.

Step 4: Implement the contact management functionality. This includes creating a Contact class with attributes for the contact's email and blocked status, and methods for blocking and unblocking the contact. The User class should also have a method for creating, editing, and managing groups, which can be represented as lists of Contacts. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that contacts can be blocked and unblocked, and that groups can be created, edited, and managed correctly.

Step 5: Implement the messaging functionality. This includes creating a Message class with attributes for the sender, receiver, content, read receipt status, and encryption status. The User class should have methods for sending and receiving messages, which should create Message instances and store them in a mock database. The Message class should also have a method for encrypting the content. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that messages can be sent, received, and encrypted correctly.

Step 6: Implement the group chat functionality. This includes adding methods to the User class for creating a group chat, adding or removing participants, and setting admin roles and permissions. The Group Chat can be represented as a subclass of the Contact class, with additional attributes for the name, picture, participants, and admin roles. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that group chats can be created, participants can be added or removed, and admin roles and permissions can be set correctly.

Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes adding methods to the User class for posting a status, which should create a Status instance and store it in a mock database. The Status class should have attributes for the content, visibility settings, and expiration time. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that statuses can be posted and retrieved correctly, and that they expire after the correct amount of time.

Step 8: Implement the web application functionality. This includes setting up the routes in the app.py file for the different functionalities, and creating HTML templates for the different pages. The Flask framework should be used to serve the web application. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that the web application can be accessed and navigated correctly.

Step 9: Implement the connectivity and offline mode functionality. This includes adding a 'online' attribute to the User class, and methods for going online and offline. When a user is offline, messages they send should be queued and sent when they go online. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that the online/offline status can be set and retrieved correctly, and that messages are queued and sent correctly when a user is offline.

Step 10: Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire system. This includes running all the tests written in the previous steps, and writing additional tests if necessary to cover all functionalities. Ensure that all tests pass and that the application works as expected. If any tests fail, debug the corresponding code and fix the issues until all tests pass.
step: Step 6: Implement the group chat functionality. This includes adding methods to the User class for creating a group chat, adding or removing participants, and setting admin roles and permissions. The Group Chat can be represented as a subclass of the Contact class, with additional attributes for the name, picture, participants, and admin roles. After implementing this, write tests to ensure that group chats can be created, participants can be added or removed, and admin roles and permissions can be set correctly.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
